title: How to Stop Windows from Freezing: Easy Troubleshooting Guide

steps.title: Wait a few moments for your system to catch up.
steps.content: Wait a few moments for your system to catch up. If your PC hangs while doing something processor- or RAM-intensive, it might unfreeze on its own if you give it some time. Instead of clicking around or trying to close programs, try waiting to see if the problem resolves on its own. If the screen went black when your computer froze, try pressing Windows key + Ctrl + Shift + B to reset your video card drivers. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: End hung tasks in the Task Manger.
steps.content: End hung tasks in the Task Manger. If your PC won't unfreeze on its own, press Control + Shift + Esc at the same time to display all open apps in Task Manager . [2] X Research source If you can't open Task Manager this way, try pressing Ctrl + Alt + Del and then clicking Task Manager . You can also right-click the Start menu and select Task Manager . Once Task Manager opens, look for the app using the most CPU, Memory, Disk, or GPU resources. To stop the problem app, click its name and select End Task . It may take a few moments for the app to close.

steps.title: Restart your PC
steps.content: Restart your PC . If your PC is still unresponsive and/or you can't open the Task Manager, there's not much else you can do until you restart your PC. Press and hold the Power button on your laptop or desktop computer until the screen turns off, then press the Power button again to turn it back on. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If your PC's screen turned blue before it froze (an error known as the Blue Screen of Death ), you can analyze the crash dump files to see which software, hardware, or drivers lead to the crash.

steps.title: Start and shut down your PC without any devices or peripherals plugged in.
steps.content: Start and shut down your PC without any devices or peripherals plugged in. If your PC hangs when booting into Windows, when shutting down, or while restarting, a connected device might be interfering with the startup process. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Unplug any USB flash drives, phones, printers, and other devices before starting up or shutting down your PC to prevent these system hangs.

steps.title: Open the Windows Security panel.
steps.content: Open the Windows Security panel. If Windows keeps freezing, it's a good idea to check for a malware or virus infection . This is super easy to do with Windows Defender, which comes preinstalled on your PC. To open Windows Security: Press Windows key + S and type security . Click Windows Security .

steps.title: Click Virus & Threat Protection.
steps.content: Click Virus & Threat Protection . This is the tile with a blue shield. Information about your last virus scan will appear. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Scan options.
steps.content: Click Scan options . While you could click Quick Scan to quickly detect obvious threats, this option won't check all the files on your PC. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select a scan type.
steps.content: Select a scan type. Choose from one of these two scan types: Full scan: This does a deep scan of all files on your PC and can take up to an hour. Microsoft Defender Antivirus (offline scan): This scan reboots your PC into safe mode without internet support to remove more difficult malware. The scan shouldn't take more than 15 minutes.

steps.title: Click Scan now and follow the on-screen instructions.
steps.content: Click Scan now and follow the on-screen instructions. If you chose the offline scan, your PC will reboot before the scan begins. Once the scan is complete, follow the on-screen instructions to quarantine and remove any detected threats.

steps.title: Open the Windows Update panel.
steps.content: Open the Windows Update panel. If there's a problem with a driver or your PC's firmware, there may be an update available that resolves the issue. Driver and firmware updates are typically bundled with Windows Updates , but you can also check for updates on your PC manufacturer's website. To get started: [7] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Click the Windows Start menu and select Settings . For Windows 10, click Update & Security > Windows Update . On Windows 11, just click Windows Update .

steps.title: Click Check for updates.
steps.content: Click Check for updates . This checks for any recent updates to Windows, supported software, drivers, and firmware. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Install all updates.
steps.content: Install all updates. If updates are available, follow the on-screen instructions to install. Depending on the updates installed, you may have to reboot your PC for the update to take effect. If prompted, click Restart now to reboot. Sometimes BIOS/UEFI updates , third-party hardware, and other manufacturer updates won't be available through Windows Update. You can check your manufacturer's support website to find out if any updates are available directly through them. If a BIOS update is available, make sure your PC is plugged in to a reliable power source before flashing the BIOS. Otherwise, if your PC loses power during the update, you could render your computer unbootable.

steps.title: Open the System Configuration panel.
steps.content: Open the System Configuration panel. If a certain app that launches automatically is causing your system to freeze, you can disable it in your startup options. But first, try running Windows with a Selective Startup so you can see if your PC continues to freeze without your startup items. To open System Configuration: Press Windows key + S . Type msconfig and press Enter .

steps.title: Click the General tab.
steps.content: Click the General tab. This displays three options for starting your PC.

steps.title: Select Selective startup.
steps.content: Select Selective startup . It's the third option.

steps.title: Remove the checkmark from "Load startup items."
steps.content: Remove the checkmark from "Load startup items." Leave the other items checked.

steps.title: Click OK and restart your PC.
steps.content: Click OK and restart your PC. When your PC reboots, see if you can recreate the problem that cause Windows to hang or freeze. If Windows no longer freezes, the issue is likely being caused by one of the apps set to launch automatically.

steps.title: Open your Startup Apps.
steps.content: Open your Startup Apps. Now you can choose which apps will start automatically and which you'll have to start manually. Press Windows key + S and type startup apps . Click Startup Apps in the search results. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Toggle off any apps that you don't need to launch automatically.
steps.content: Toggle off any apps that you don't need to launch automatically. Not only can a rogue startup app cause your PC to freeze, it can also make Windows run more slowly. Toggle off any apps you don't want to launch automatically each time you boot up your PC. [10] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source You can always launch these apps from the Start menu as needed even if they don't start automatically.

steps.title: Re-open System Configuration.
steps.content: Re-open System Configuration. This is the tool you used before. Just press Windows key + S , type msconfig , then press Enter .

steps.title: Check the box next to "Load startup items."
steps.content: Check the box next to "Load startup items." You'll want to leave "Selective startup" checked as well.

steps.title: Click OK to save your changes.
steps.content: Click OK to save your changes. Now when you reboot your PC, Windows will start with only the applications you allowed to launch automatically.

steps.title: Press Control + X on the keyboard.
steps.content: Press Control + X on the keyboard. This opens the Power User menu, where you'll find a quick link to run the command prompt or Windows PowerShell as an administrator. You can use this tool to scan for and repair correct Windows system files, which can help fix issues with freezing and hanging.

steps.title: Click Command Prompt (Admin) or Windows PowerShell (Admin).
steps.content: Click Command Prompt (Admin) or Windows PowerShell (Admin) . You can run the system file checker from either of these locations. [11] X Research source If you're using Windows 11, you may see Windows Terminal (Admin) . This will work, too.

steps.title: Type DISM.exe /Online /Cleanup-image /Restorehealth and press Enter.
steps.content: Type DISM.exe /Online /Cleanup-image /Restorehealth and press Enter . If you're using Windows 8.1, Windows 10, or Windows 11, run this command before scanning the file system. [12] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you're using Windows 7, skip this step. This command connects to Windows Update to get the necessary files required to fix corruption. It can take up to 30 minutes to complete, but typically won't take that long. After a few moments, you'll see "The operation completed successfully." At that point, you can continue to the next step.

steps.title: Type SFC /scannow and press Enter.
steps.content: Type SFC /scannow and press Enter . This checks your system files, which may take several minutes. Make sure you don't close the window while the scan is in progress. [13] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If corrupted files are detected, they'll be replaced with repaired versions. If the scan does not find corruption, you'll see the message "Windows Resource Protection did not find any integrity violations." If you see a message that says, "Windows Resource Protection could not perform the requested operation," try running the scan again in Safe Mode .

steps.title: Open the Windows File Explorer.
steps.content: Open the Windows File Explorer. You can do this by right-clicking the Start menu and selecting File Explorer or by clicking the folder icon on your taskbar. If your hard drive is not performing properly, it could cause your PC to freeze. Fortunately, you can easily check your hard drive from File Explorer. If you have multiple hard drives, remember to check them all.

steps.title: Click This PC.
steps.content: Click This PC . You'll see this in the left panel. A list of all connected drives will appear in the right panel.

steps.title: Right-click your hard drive and select Properties.
steps.content: Right-click your hard drive and select Properties . A dialog window with several tabs will appear.

steps.title: Click the Tools tab.
steps.content: Click the Tools tab. This displays options for error checking and optimization.

steps.title: Click Check.
steps.content: Click Check . You'll be prompted to scan your hard drive.

steps.title: Click Scan drive.
steps.content: Click Scan drive . Windows will now scan the selected hard drive for errors. [14] X Research source If any errors are detected, Windows will attempt to repair them. Repeat for all drives connected to your PC.

steps.title: Open the Windows Memory Diagnostic tool.
steps.content: Open the Windows Memory Diagnostic tool. If your RAM is bad, your PC will seemingly freeze at random, often leaving you no other option than to do a hard reboot. Fortunately, Windows comes with a free RAM checking tool. To open it: First, save any work you have open, as your PC will reboot to use the tool. Press Windows key + S . Type mdsched.exe and press Enter .

steps.title: Click Restart now and check for problems (recommended).
steps.content: Click Restart now and check for problems (recommended) . This option will instantly reboot your PC and run a memory scan outside of Windows. The scan may take a while, so feel free to get up and come back later. Because this tool won't always show the test results, we'll show you how to find them once Windows boots back up.

steps.title: When the scan is finished, right-click the Start menu and select Event Viewer.
steps.content: When the scan is finished, right-click the Start menu and select Event Viewer . When the scan is complete, your PC will boot back into Windows. To see the results, you'll need to check the Event Viewer. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Click Windows Logs in the left panel.
steps.content: Click Windows Logs in the left panel. Several logs will appear below. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Right-click the "System" log and select Find....
steps.content: Right-click the "System" log and select Find... . The "Find" window will expand.

steps.title: Type MemoryDiagnostics and click Find Next.
steps.content: Type MemoryDiagnostics and click Find Next . This searches the system log for all entries created by the Windows Memory Diagnostic Tool. [17] X Research source If no errors are found, the issue is not likely related to RAM.

steps.title: Press the Windows key + S and type power.
steps.content: Press the Windows key + S and type power . If your PC freezes while your PC is idle, goes to sleep, or wakes from sleep mode, you may be able to fix the freezing issue in your power settings. When you type power , several search results will appear.

steps.title: Click Edit power plan.
steps.content: Click Edit power plan . This displays information about your current power plan.

steps.title: Click Change advanced power settings.
steps.content: Click Change advanced power settings . This appears below the general settings for the plan.

steps.title: Double-click PCI Express.
steps.content: Double-click PCI Express . Another option will expand.

steps.title: Double-click Link State Power Management.
steps.content: Double-click Link State Power Management . Now you'll see options for configuring your power settings for this item. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Select Off from the menu(s).
steps.content: Select Off from the menu(s). If you're using a laptop, you'll want to choose Off from both menus.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . Disabling this feature often resolves issues of freezing caused by power and sleep settings. If this doesn't resolve your issue, you can return to your power options to reenable Link State Power Management. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Disk Cleanup tool.
steps.content: Open the Disk Cleanup tool. If your Windows cache contains any corrupt files or your hard drive is getting full, you might experience system crashes and freezes. You can easily get rid of all unnecessary files, including temporary Windows files , in Disk Cleanup. To open the tool: Press Windows key + S . Type disk cleanup . Click Disk Cleanup . [20] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Clean up system files.
steps.content: Click Clean up system files . You'll see this at the bottom-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Select which files to delete.
steps.content: Select which files to delete. If you just want to delete temporary files created by Windows, check the boxes next to "Temporary files" and "Temporary Windows installation files." You can also select other options, such as "Recycle Bin," if you want to free up some space in general.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . A confirmation message will appear.

steps.title: Click Delete Files to confirm.
steps.content: Click Delete Files to confirm. Once the files are deleted, the tool will close. If you're still low on hard drive space, your PC may continue to freeze and crash. Check out these tricks for freeing up hard drive space.

steps.title: Click the Start menu and select Settings.
steps.content: Click the Start menu and select Settings . If your PC started freezing after a Windows Update, you can try rolling back the update to see if that resolves the problem. [21] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you're unable to use Windows at all because it keeps freezing, try booting into Safe Mode before you perform these steps.

steps.title: Click Update & Security (Windows 10).
steps.content: Click Update & Security (Windows 10). If you're using Windows 11, you can skip this step. [22] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Windows Update.
steps.content: Click Windows Update . This opens the Windows Update panel. [23] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click View Update History or Update history.
steps.content: Click View Update History or Update history . You'll see one of these two options depending on your operating system. [24] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Uninstall updates.
steps.content: Click Uninstall updates . It's at the bottom of the right panel on Windows 11, and at the top of Windows 10. [25] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select the most recent update.
steps.content: Select the most recent update. You'll see a list of all recent Windows Updates here, as well as some other apps that have update features built in. Click the most recent update that occurred around the time your PC started freezing or hanging.

steps.title: Click Uninstall.
steps.content: Click Uninstall . You'll see this at the top of the list. This removes the selected update from your PC. Most updates will attempt to reinstall automatically, so you might want to pause updates to see if uninstalling this latest update fixes your problem. To pause updates, return to Windows Updates and select a time period on "Pause Updates."

steps.title: Open the Windows Control Panel.
steps.content: Open the Windows Control Panel. If you think you know when your PC started freezing, you can try restoring your system to a point in time before the freezing began. To open Control Panel, press Windows key + S , type control panel , then click Control Panel .

steps.title: Type recovery into the search bar.
steps.content: Type recovery into the search bar. You'll see this search bar at the top-right corner of Control Panel. [26] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Recovery in the search results.
steps.content: Click Recovery in the search results. This displays your advanced recovery options.

steps.title: Click Open System Restore.
steps.content: Click Open System Restore . If System Restore is enabled, you'll see the most recent recommended restore point, as well as the option to choose an alternative. If you don't have any restore points, you'll need to try another method.

steps.title: Select a restore point.
steps.content: Select a restore point. If the recommended restore point is too recent, click Choose a different restore point and select Next to find an earlier one.

steps.title: Click Scan for affected programs.
steps.content: Click Scan for affected programs . This option tells you which software will be removed and which updates will be rolled back if you were to continue with the system restore. When you're finished, click Close . System Restore will not affect your personal files.

steps.title: Click Finish to restore your PC.
steps.content: Click Finish to restore your PC. This restores your PC to the selected time and date.

steps.title: Click Search and type power button.
steps.content: Click Search and type power button . Older PCs sometimes hang at boot time when Fast Startup is enabled. [27] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source To disable Fast Startup, start by typing power button into Search.

steps.title: Click Change what the power buttons do.
steps.content: Click Change what the power buttons do .

steps.title: Click Change settings that are currently unavailable.
steps.content: Click Change settings that are currently unavailable . Now you'll see the option to enable or disable Fast Startup.

steps.title: Remove the checkmark from "Turn on Fast Startup."
steps.content: Remove the checkmark from "Turn on Fast Startup." Disabling this feature will often stop your Windows 8.1 PC from freezing during startup.

steps.title: Click Save changes.
steps.content: Click Save changes . The next time you reboot your PC, it should no longer freeze.

steps.title: Click the Start menu and select Settings.
steps.content: Click the Start menu and select Settings . If your computer is still freezing, you can try resetting your PC. Fortunately, you can now reset your PC's settings without losing your personal data. Start by opening your Settings. [28] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click System (Windows 11) or Update & Security (Windows 10).
steps.content: Click System (Windows 11) or Update & Security (Windows 10). [29] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Recovery.
steps.content: Click Recovery . You'll see this in the right panel on Windows 11, and on the left panel in Windows 10. [30] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Reset PC (Windows 11) or Get Started (Windows 10).
steps.content: Click Reset PC (Windows 11) or Get Started (Windows 10). [31] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Choose whether to keep your files or start from scratch.
steps.content: Choose whether to keep your files or start from scratch. To make sure you don't lose any data other than installed apps and modified settings, select Keep my files . But if you want to erase all of your personal files and apps you've installed, you can select Remove everything . [32] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Follow the on-screen instructions to reset your PC.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen instructions to reset your PC. Once your PC comes back up, try using it for a while to see if it still freezes. If the freezing does not continue, reinstall your apps one by one to narrow down the problem. If a particular app brings back the symptoms, the issue is related to that app or a device driver it uses to run. If the freezing continues after resetting your PC and doesn't correlate with an app or device you've installed, the issue is likely hardware related.
